==== 2 February ====
==== 2 February ====
â
During the night of 1â2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria; shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 2 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref> In Cairo, many of the protesters from the the previous day's protest decided to sleep and remain in Tahrir Square and more protesters are coming.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] is sending hundreds of activists to show support to Hosni Mubarak.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} The army is asking the protesters to go home.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There was also unrest in Port Said.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
+
During the night of 1â2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria; shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 2 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref> In Cairo, many of the protesters from the the previous day's protest decided to sleep and remain in Tahrir Square and more protesters are coming.<ref>http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] is sending hundreds of activists to show support to Hosni Mubarak.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} The army is asking the protesters to go home.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There was also unrest in Port Said.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
At 12:00 local time, internet access in Egypt has been at least partially restored and the night-time curfew in Egypt has been eased. It will now run from 5pm to 7am instead of 3pm to 8am.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref> The pro-Mubarak activists attacked [[Al Arabiya]] reporter Ahmed Bagato while he was trying to show them harassing the anti-Mubarak protesters.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref>''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February, 2011. 16:00</ref>
At 12:00 local time, internet access in Egypt has been at least partially restored and the night-time curfew in Egypt has been eased. It will now run from 5pm to 7am instead of 3pm to 8am.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref> The pro-Mubarak activists attacked [[Al Arabiya]] reporter Ahmed Bagato while he was trying to show them harassing the anti-Mubarak protesters.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref>''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February, 2011. 16:00</ref>
